The Gold Reserve Act of 1934 set up a stabilizationfund and made explicit the role of the Treasury in intervening in the foreignexchange market. However, because the stabilization fund was endowed onlywith gold, it was technically able to only counteract gold outflows, not goldinflows (see Johnson (1939, pp. 92—114)).
